commands.name: Step 1: Review Auto-Sync Policy
commands.description: Review the Application CR with automated sync policy
commands.explanation: Notice the syncPolicy section with 'automated', 'prune: true', and 'selfHeal: true'. This means ArgoCD will automatically deploy changes from Git, remove resources not in Git, and revert manual changes.
commands.what_it_does: Displays the Application CR with auto-sync and self-heal enabled.
commands.next_step: Apply it and watch ArgoCD deploy automatically.

commands.name: Step 2: Apply the Application CR
commands.description: Create the application - ArgoCD will auto-sync immediately
commands.explanation: Unlike Scenario 01, this app has automated sync. ArgoCD will immediately detect the new Application and begin deploying resources without manual intervention.
commands.what_it_does: Creates the Application with auto-sync enabled in ArgoCD.
commands.next_step: Watch ArgoCD automatically deploy the resources.

commands.name: Step 3: Watch Auto-Deployment
commands.description: Open ArgoCD UI and watch the app auto-sync - no SYNC button needed
commands.explanation: In the ArgoCD UI, watch the application transition from OutOfSync to Synced automatically. No manual SYNC button needed! The status should quickly show 'Synced' and 'Healthy'.
commands.what_it_does: Shows the auto-sync in action through the ArgoCD UI.
info_steps: Open ArgoCD UI (use the button above)
Watch it transition from OutOfSync to Synced automatically — no SYNC button needed!
The status should quickly show Synced and Healthy

commands.name: Step 4: Verify Auto-Deployed Resources
commands.description: Check that pods were automatically created by ArgoCD
commands.explanation: You should see 3 running pods. ArgoCD deployed them automatically when it detected the Application CR. No manual sync was needed.
commands.what_it_does: Lists pods in the scenario namespace to confirm auto-deployment.
commands.next_step: Now test the self-heal feature by deleting a pod.

commands.name: Step 5: Test Self-Heal - Delete a Pod
commands.command: kubectl delete pod -n argocd-sc-02 -l app=autosync-app --grace-period=0 --force 2>/dev/null && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-02
commands.description: Delete a pod and watch ArgoCD restore it
commands.explanation: When you delete a pod, the Deployment controller recreates it. But if you modify the deployment itself (e.g., change replicas), ArgoCD's self-heal will revert it. Let's test that next.
commands.what_it_does: Deletes a pod to demonstrate Kubernetes + ArgoCD recovery.
commands.next_step: Test self-heal by manually changing the replica count.

commands.name: Step 6: Test Self-Heal - Change Replicas
commands.command: kubectl scale deployment autosync-app -n argocd-sc-02 --replicas=1 && kubectl get pods -n argocd-sc-02
commands.description: Scale to 1 replica - ArgoCD will revert back to 3
commands.explanation: ArgoCD detected that the live state (1 replica) differs from the desired state in Git (3 replicas). Self-heal automatically reverts the change. Check the ArgoCD UI to see the sync event.
commands.what_it_does: Manually changes replicas and watches ArgoCD revert the drift.

commands.name: Step 7: Verify Self-Heal in ArgoCD UI
commands.description: Check ArgoCD UI for self-heal sync events
commands.explanation: In the ArgoCD UI, the app should show 'Synced'. Check the History tab to see multiple sync events - the automatic syncs triggered by self-heal. This proves ArgoCD is actively enforcing the desired state.
commands.what_it_does: Guides you to verify self-heal events in the ArgoCD UI.
commands.next_step: Scenario complete! Clean up when ready.
info_steps: Open ArgoCD UI (use the button above)
Check the HISTORY tab — you'll see multiple sync events triggered by self-heal
The app should show Synced with 3 replicas restored automatically

commands.name: Cleanup: Delete Application
commands.command: kubectl delete application sc02-auto-sync -n argocd && kubectl delete namespace argocd-sc-02 --ignore-not-found
commands.description: Remove the ArgoCD application and namespace
commands.explanation: Deleting the Application stops ArgoCD management. The namespace deletion removes all deployed resources.
commands.what_it_does: Removes the application and all resources.
